review.title: Containment, Equivalence and Coreness from CSP to QCSP and beyond
review.abstract: The constraint satisfaction problem (CSP) and its quantified extensions, whether without (QCSP) or with disjunction (QCSP_or), correspond naturally to the model checking problem for three increasingly stronger fragments of positive first-order logic. Their complexity is often studied when parameterised by a fixed model, the so-called template.

sections.heading: 5.2 Unary structures
sections.text: We write w (x) as an abbreviation for the quantifier-free formula [1] ≤ i ≤ n, w [i] = 1Mi (x). Each element a of a simple structure A corresponds to a word w, which is bitwise the largest word, so that A | = w (x / a). Let w (c) be the bitwise indication of the words associated with each element. The simple structure A fulfills the canonical universal proposition. (Note: w) is also the largest word among such satisfied universal formulas. (sentence 4) The Q core of a simple structure A is the unique substructure of A. The Q core of an existential proposition is the logical core A ², if a universal proposition is bitwise the largest word among such satisfied universal formulas. (sentence 4) The Q core of a simple structure A is the unique substructure of A that follows.

sections.heading: 5.3 Structures with an isolated element
sections.text: We say that a pH set is a proper pH set if it has at least one universal quantifiable variable that occurs in some form or other (otherwise we would simply reject a set with a less variable set). We will say that a proper pH set can only be produced by a proper pH set, and we will always work with a proper set that consists of a proper pH set that is a proper subordination by removing some subjunctive. Let us be a signature consisting of an infinite number of relation symbols of each species ri. We will look at the set of minimum pH sets w.r.t. This is all formulas of the form x1.

sections.heading: 6 The usefulness of Q-cores
sections.text: The graphs are relationship structures with a single symmetrical relationship. We call them partially reflexive (p.r.) to emphasize that each vertex can have either a self-loop or not. A p.r. tree can contain self-loops, but no larger cycle Cn for n ≥ 3. A p.r. tree contains at most one such cycle Cn for n ≥ 3. A p.r. forest (or pseudo-forest) is the dissolved union of p.r. trees (or pseudo-forest). Since p.r. forests (or pseudo-forests) are closed under sub-structures, we can be sure that a Q-core of a p.r. forest (or pseudo-forest) is a p.r. forest (or pseudo-forest).

sections.heading: 6.1 Partially reflexive forests
sections.text: It is not true that if H is a p.r. forest, then either H admits a majority polymorphism, then Q + tex, and QCSP (H) is in NL, or QCSP (H) is NP-hard. Suggestion 5. Let H be a p.r. forest. Then, either the Q core of H admits a majority polymorphism, and QCSP − P (H) is in NL, or QCSP (H) is NP-hard.Proof. We assume that graphs have at least one edge (otherwise the Q core is K1). Irreflective forests are a special case of two-part graphs, which are all equivalent. -FO, their Q core is K2, if they do not have an isolated vertex (see example 3) and K2 otherwise.We assume that graphs have at least one edge and one self-loop.

sections.heading: 6.2 Irreflexive Pseudoforests
sections.text: A pseudo-forest is the dissolved union of a collection of pseudotrees.Proposal 6. Let H be an irreflexive pseudo-forest. Then, either the Q nucleus of H permits majority polymorphism, and QCSP (H) is in NL, or QCSP (H) is NP-Hard.Proof. We follow the classification of [15]. If H is split in two, then its Q nucleus is either K2, K1, K2 + K1 (see [6]), and this permits majority polymorphism. Otherwise, its Q nucleus contains a strange cycle that does not allow majority polymorphism, and QCSP (H) is NP-hard.

sections.heading: 8 Conclusion
sections.text: We have introduced the concept of the Q-core and have shown that it does not possess all the properties of cores and U-X-core. Specifically, in the equivalence class of structures that agree on pH rates, there does not have to be a unique minimum element of size. However, we assume that the concept of the Q-core that we give is robust, since the Q-core of each structure is unique up to the isomorphism; and that it sits in each sub-structure of B, the same theorem of {, which is a prerequivalence of each structure, a prerequivalence of each structure to the isomorphism; and that it sits in each substructure of {, a prerequivalence of a prerequivalence of a prerequivalence of a prerequivalence of a prerequivalence of a prerequivalence of a prerequivalence of a).

In Section 3, we recall results on coreness and spell out containment for {∃,∀,∧,∨}-FO that were only implicit in [13].
In Section 4, we move on to QCSP and recall results on the decidability of containment from [6] together with new lower bounds before initiating a study of the notion of core for QCSP.
Containment for {∃,∧}-FO is a special case of conjunctive query containment from databases [5].
It is well known that the core is unique up to isomorphism and that it is an induced substructure [12].
The notion of a core can be extended and adapted suitably to solve important questions related to data exchange and query rewriting in databases [8].
It is also very useful as a simplifying assumption when classifying the complexity: with the algebraic approach, it allows to study only idempotent algebras [4].
Checking that a graph is a core is coNP-complete [10].

If T is loop-connected, then it admits a majority polymorphism [14].
If T is quasi-loop-connected, then it is QCSP-equivalent to one of its subtrees that is loop-connected [14] which will be its Q-core.
In all other cases QCSP(T ) is NP-hard, and T does not admit majority [14].
We follow the classification of [15].
If H is bipartite, then its Q-core is either K2, K1, K2 +K1 (see [6]) and this admits a majority polymorphism.

Furthermore, we know that the U -X-core can be identified by specific surjective hypermorphisms that act as the identity on X and contain the identity on U [13] which makes the search for the U -X-core somewhat easier than its definition suggest (see Algorithm 2).

Just as the pH-theory of structures with an isolated element is essentially determined by their pp-theory, so the pH-theory of disconnected structures is essentially determined by its ∀∃∗ fragment (see [15]).

metadata.abstractText: The constraint satisfaction problem (CSP) and its quantified extensions, whether without (QCSP) or with disjunction (QCSP∨), correspond naturally to the model checking problem for three increasingly stronger fragments of positive first-order logic. Their complexity is often studied when parameterised by a fixed model, the so-called template. It is a natural question to ask when two templates are equivalent, or more generally when one “contain” another, in the sense that a satisfied instance of the first will be necessarily satisfied in the second. One can also ask for a smallest possible equivalent template: this is known as the core for CSP. We recall and extend previous results on containment, equivalence and “coreness” for QCSP∨ before initiating a preliminary study of cores for QCSP which we characterise for certain structures and which turns out to be more elusive.
